snippet: The United States signaled impatience with the Syrian opposition-in-exile and said it would support a more robust movement to oust President Bashar al-Assad.
abstract: Sec of State Hillary Rodham Clinton, as part of the United States' most aggressive attempt yet to reshape Syrian opposition,  dismisses opposition group Syrian National Council as out-of-touch exiles who should be replaced; hundreds of opposition figures plan to gather in Doha, Quatar, to form new leadership, ostensibly under auspices of Arab League but Clinton says she had been heavily involved in the planning.

byline.original: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR and MICHAEL R. GORDON
byline.contributor: Neil MacFarquhar reported from Beirut, and Michael R. Gordon from Zagreb, Croatia. Hania Mourtada and Hwaida Saad contributed reporting from Beirut, and Hala Droubi from Dubai, United Arab Emirates.

lead_paragraph: The United States signaled impatience with the Syrian opposition-in-exile and said it would support a more robust movement to oust President Bashar al-Assad.

headline.seo: As Fighting Rages in Syria, Clinton Calls for New Opposition Movement
headline.main: As Fighting Rages, Clinton Seeks New Syrian Opposition
headline.print_headline: As Fighting Rages in Syria, Clinton Seeks New Opposition Movement
